title-group.article-title: Essential amino acid enriched meal replacement improves body composition and physical function in obese older adults: A randomized controlled trial

article-meta.aff: aMontana Center for Work Physiology and Exercise Metabolism, University of Montana, Missoula, MT, USA
bInstitute of Arctic Biology, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK, USA
cHonors College, James Madison University, Harrisonburg, VA, USA
dDonald W. Reynolds Institute on Aging, University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, Little Rock, AR, USA

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Older adults are threatened by the risk of muscle atrophy and excess accumulation of adipose tissue. The objective of this study was to determine whether an essential amino acid enriched meal replacement would reduce excess fat and foster skeletal muscle retention, potentially improving physical function in this cohort.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Using a double blind, randomized controlled trial, we compared the influence of an experimental meal replacement enriched with essential amino acids (EMR) to a commercially available, widely used meal replacement (Optifast®) provided once/day (q.d.) for four weeks on body composition, skeletal muscle and physical function in obese older participants. Twenty-eight individuals completed either EMR (n = 13) or Optifast® (n = 15) supplementation protocols. Measurements of body composition, thigh skeletal muscle cross-sectional area (CSA), blood panels, intrahepatic lipid, and physical function were completed pre- and post-supplementation.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Body fat mass, visceral fat mass and volume, and intrahepatic lipid were reduced with EMR but not with Optifast®. Thigh muscle CSA increased (Δ 2.4 ± 3.0 cm2) with EMR but not Optifast® (Δ −1.8 ± 6.0 cm2). There was a significant increase in the distance covered during the 6-min walk test with EMR (Δ 23 ± 27 m) but no change in Optifast® (Δ 11 ± 37 m).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Beneficial alterations in fat and muscle support the use of EMR-based meal replacements in obese older adults.

sec.title: Clinical Trial Registration:
sec.p: ISRCTN registry under Reference Number ISRCTN15814848.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The progressive, deleterious loss of muscle mass that occurs with aging is called sarcopenia [1]. Muscle atrophy in conjunction with obesity is particularly problematic, as the load required for functional independence is increased, but with depleted contractile [2]. Age related accumulation of adipose tissue has been linked to decreased mitochondrial function, lipid infiltration into muscle and liver, chronic inflammation and insulin resistance (3). It is not surprising that sarcopenic obesity has also been associated with the development of metabolic diseases [3]. In other words, the concomitant presentation of muscle atrophy and obesity simultaneously conflates the consequences of reduced physical activity in individuals who are already at high risk. While losing weight might seem like the obvious solution, data from epidemiological studies suggest an obesity paradox by which body weight has a protective effect against mortality [4]. The efficacy of weight loss in addressing sarcopenic obesity is further complicated by low fitness levels in older, obese adults [5]; not surprisingly co-mingled with low interest in physical activity as a viable intervention [6]. Moreover, most individuals, prefer dietary modification as their only strategy to improve body composition and overall health [6].

In addition to the connection between sarcopenic obesity and metabolic syndrome that may affect almost 50% of individuals over the age of 60 [5], inadequate nutritional intake can be a significant concern as well [7]. For example, a decline in the quality of the diet can lead to suboptimal body composition and further exacerbate the risks of disability among older adults [8]. To address these concerns, many individuals and health care providers utilize meal replacements to help maintain body weight and functional independence [9]. While the use of standard meal replacements like Optifast® may be effective for weight management in young to middle-aged populations [10], it is quite possible that the overall efficacy of standard meal replacements may be limited by the presence of anabolic resistance in older individuals [11].

The acute benefits of a meal replacement enriched with essential amino acids (EAAs) compared to standard meal replacements on whole body net protein balance under isocaloric conditions in older individuals have been previously established [12]. In these studies that incorporated stable isotope methodology, higher net protein balance was influenced by the provision of specific amounts of EAAs and non-essential amino acids required for overcoming anabolic resistance [13]. The popularity of meal replacements is widespread, and the use of dietary strategies to improve overall health is broad. However, longitudinal, well-controlled evaluations designed to study the efficacy of EAA-based meal replacements on metabolic health and physical function in older individuals are sparse. Using a randomized controlled trial study design and a per protocol analytical approach, we tested the hypothesis that once/day (q.d.) consumption of an EAA-enriched meal replacement (EMR) would promote improvements in body composition, skeletal muscle, intrahepatic lipid, and physical function compared to an isocaloric commercially available meal replacement (i.e., Optifast®) in obese older individuals (see Table 1 for Nutritional Composition of EMR and Optifast®).

sec.title: Recruitment
sec.p: We posted informational flyers and newsletters on the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) campus. We also held brief informational presentations for the purpose of educating seniors in our community, providing them with an opportunity to participate in the study described herein. Individuals from all racial, ethnic, and/or cultural backgrounds between the ages of 60–85 years old with a body mass index of 26–40 kg/m2 were encouraged to participate. Anyone interested in the trial was encouraged to call our secure, telephone answering service, which allowed private and individual telephone conversations to assess eligibility.

This study was powered to evaluate changes in body composition in an obese older cohort based on the energy cost of EMR-induced alterations in protein metabolism [14]. Therefore, no attempt was made to stratify participants according to age or gender. The project (Nutrient Strategies for Muscle Preservation: 986801-17) and all related documents were approved on 17 September 2017 by the UAF Institutional Review Board. Recruitment began on 18 September 2017 and ended on 31 October 2018. All participants provided written informed consent prior to participation. Our randomized controlled trial is listed with the International Stand Randomised Controlled Trial Number (ISRCTN) registry under Reference Number ISRCTN15814848. The ISRCTN registry is recognized by the World Health Organization and the International Committee of Medical Journal Editors.

sec.title: Exclusion criteria
sec.p: Individuals with a pacemaker or other implanted metal device or object, or who had been previously diagnosed with insulin dependent diabetes, active cancer or malignancy, or a chronic inflammatory condition were excluded. Individuals taking medications, supplements, or corticosteroids that might have influenced metabolism were not enrolled. Finally, any individual with a disease or condition that would have placed them at risk or caused harm to themselves or others were also excluded. Participants were weight stable and not participating in a weight loss or exercise program at the time of enrollment.

sec.title: Study participants
sec.p: The participants were screened over the phone for basic inclusion/exclusion criteria. If accepted, the participants underwent additional screening via a health history questionnaire and anthropometric measurements by the study staff. We assessed fifty-three participants for eligibility by telephone screening. Once individuals were deemed eligible for participation, we enrolled thirty-seven obese older males and females of all races and ethnic backgrounds into a double blind, parallel, randomized controlled trial (Fig. 1) (Table 2). A computerized, random number generator was used for group assignment. Two individuals whose body mass index (BMI) was slightly outside the range (ie., 43 and 44 kg/m2) were inadvertently enrolled and randomized for participation. This protocol deviation was reported to the Institutional Review Board at UAF. An individual not affiliated with the study or the academic program was responsible for blinding of the meal replacements. All researchers including our biostatistician (Dr. Barati) were blinded to treatment assignment. Study codes were unblinded following the completion of all statistical analysis.

Based on random assignment, participants were asked to consume either EMR or Optifast® once/day for 4 weeks in lieu of their lunch time meal. Given that the meal replacements contained 160 calories, this likely resulted in a reduction in caloric intake at least for the lunch meal itself. Thirteen individuals completed their EMR assignment. Fifteen individuals completed their Optifast® assignment. Compliance was measured weekly using the weigh-back method, in which the researchers measured the weight of the product consumed and divided that by the weight that should have been consumed. Compliance to protocol was evaluated in all study participants, and the potential differences between EMR and Optifast® were analyzed. Using these compliance assessment strategies, twenty-seven of the participants were 80% or more compliant, with one participant being 55% compliant. There were no significant differences in compliance between the two groups.

We made no attempt to modify any other aspect of dietary intake or suggest any alteration in physical activity to our participants. Of the twenty-two participants randomized to EMR, two were lost to follow-up, five withdrew due to the taste of EMR, and one withdrew due to an unrelated illness. Thirteen participants completed EMR and fifteen participants completed Optifast®. Three participants failed to complete their post-intervention MRI/MRS-derived scans for intrahepatic lipid; two were assigned to EMR and one was assigned to Optifast®. The MRI image for thigh muscle CSA contained artifacts (possibly due to excessive movement) in one of the participants assigned to Optifast® and was not available for pre- or post-supplementation analysis. The nutritional composition of the meal replacements is provided in Table 1.

During pre- and post-supplementation study visits, participants completed the following: a) measurement of body weight and height, b) measurement of body composition, c) measurement of skeletal muscle cross-sectional area (CSA) of the upper thigh and intrahepatic lipid, c) physical function testing, and d) blood sampling/analysis for hepatic, lipid, and metabolic panels as described in detail below. All procedures were performed in the Clinical Research and Imaging Facility on the UAF campus except for blood sampling/analysis which was performed by LabCorp (1626, 30th Avenue, Fairbanks, AK). Participants returned once each week for research staff to record their body weight and the weight of any leftover EMR or Optifast® product, and to provide refills of their respective meal replacement. Participants refrained from alcohol consumption (24 h) and intense physical activities (72 h) prior to pre- and post-supplementation study visits. The study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki, and the protocol (#1427567-12) was approved by the UAF Institutional Review Board.

sec.title: Body composition
sec.p: Body mass and height was measured using an electronic scale/stadiometer (Health-o-Meter, St. McCook, IL, USA). Fat mass, lean tissue mass, visceral fat mass, and bone mineral content was provided by dual energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scans (General Electric Lunar iDXA; Madison, WI).

sec.title: Magnetic resonance imaging/spectroscopy
sec.p: The CSA of the skeletal muscles in the thigh were imaged, and intrahepatic lipid was isolated and analyzed using molecular imaging/spectroscopy (MRI/MRS) (Toshiba Excelart/Vantage 1.5 T MRI/MRS imaging system; Canon, Ōtawara, Tochigi, Japan). Seven slices of thigh muscle CSA were imaged, quantified, and averaged using Osirix (Geneva, Switzerland) [15]. Determination of intrahepatic lipid was performed in our laboratory as previously described [12].

sec.title: Physical function
sec.p: Study participants were familiarized with functional tests prior to any performance or measurements of grip strength, floor transfer time, or walking distance/speed. Participants were instructed to perform their grip strength measurements three times per hand using the hand-held dynamometer (Lafayette Instrument, Lafayette, IN), in kilograms, was obtained from averaging the second and third attempts for each hand. For the floor transfer test, we measured the amount of time required to move from a standing position to a supine position and back up to a complete standing position [14]. Prior to the 6-min walk test, the participant was instructed to walk as fast as possible without assistance for the entire 6-min period in an unobstructed hallway. Time was recorded in meters/second obtained using a stopwatch [14].

sec.title: Blood measurements
sec.p: Sampling and analysis of all metabolic, lipid, and hepatic blood panels were performed by LabCorp (1626, 30th Avenue, Fairbanks, AK) as previously described [12].

sec.title: Sample size calculation
sec.p: We conducted a priori power analysis using G*Power software [14] to calculate the required number of participants for each group [16]. A sample size of 6 individuals per group was determined to achieve 80% power for detecting an effect size (Cohen’s d) of 1.62, which was determined based on our previous study demonstrating a significant reduction in adipose tissue after an 8-week weight loss intervention with EMR meal replacement [17]. Based on our experience with previous studies, we anticipated a dropout rate of ~20%.We determined that if 14 participants were enrolled for each intervention, our study would have enough power to detect effect sizes in adipose tissue as small as 0.95 (Cohen’s d).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analyses were conducted using IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows, Version 25.0. Armonk, NY: IBM Corp. The significance criterion was set to α < 0.05 for all analyses and because of the exploratory nature of this study, no adjustment was made for multiple comparisons. In order to evaluate whether intervention based alterations in dependent variables were significantly different between groups, we normalized all variables by subtracting pre-supplementation from post-supplementation values. Data are shown as mean ± SD, unless otherwise indicated. We tested the normality assumption for all outcome variables using the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test. For normally distributed variables, independent samples t-tests for comparing EMR and Optifast® or paired samples t-tests for comparing baseline and post-intervention were used. If the normality assumption was violated, a non-parametric test, i.e. Mann–Whitney U test for independent samples or Wilcoxon Matched-Pairs Signed Ranks test for paired samples, was used.

sec.title: Research participants
sec.p: Twenty-eight obese older individuals completed 4 weeks of isocaloric q.d. ingestion of either EMR (containing 16 g of individual EAAs and 6 g of intact protein) (n = 13) or Optifast® (containing 16 g of intact protein) (n = 15) (Table 1) and completed testing related to body composition and physical function.

sec.title: Body composition
sec.p: There were no differences in baseline measurements of body composition (Table 2). Body weight, fat mass, visceral fat mass, and visceral fat volume were reduced in EMR but not in Optifast®. Lean tissue mass was not influenced by EMR or Optifast® (Table 2).

sec.title: Skeletal muscle
sec.p: Baseline thigh muscle CSA was not different (t = −0.62, p = 0.54) between EMR (134 ± 30 cm2) and Optifast® (142 ± 34 cm2). When thigh muscle CSA was subtracted from baseline (ie., post-pre), there was a significant difference (t = 2.26, p = 0.03) between EMR (Δ +2.4 ± 3.1 cm2) and Optifast® (Δ −1.8 ± 6.0 cm2) (Fig. 2).

sec.title: Liver lipid
sec.p: Baseline MRI/MRS-derived intrahepatic lipid was not different (t = 0.64, p = 0.053) between EMR and Optifast®. There was a significant reduction in MRI/MRS-derived intrahepatic lipid with EMR (p = 0.04) and no change (p = 0.39) with Optifast® (Fig. 3).

sec.title: Physical function
sec.p: There were no significant differences in baseline grip strength (kilograms), floor transfer test (seconds), or 6-min walk (meters) between the two groups. No changes in grip strength occurred with EMR or Optifast® (Table 3). The time required to perform the floor transfer test was reduced in EMR and presented a trend towards improvement in Optifast® (Table 3). There was a significant increase in the distance covered during the 6-min walk test and walking speed with EMR but no change in Optifast® (Table 3).

sec.title: Blood parameters
sec.p: Blood lipids were represented by total cholesterol, high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, low density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides. Hepatic function was characterized by protein, albumin, total bilirubin, direct bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, aspartate aminotransferase, and alanine aminotransferase. The metabolic panel was expressed by glucose, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, blood urea nitrogen/creatinine, and eGFR. All baseline blood parameters were within normal limits in both groups and not affected by supplementation except for protein, albumin, and blood urea nitrogen which increased in EMR (Table 4).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to evaluate whether consumption of EMR q.d. for 4 weeks would improve body composition in obese older individuals. Our primary conclusion is that the EMR q.d. increased thigh muscle CSA and reduced total adipose tissue mass, visceral adipose tissue and intrahepatic lipid. These beneficial changes also occurred in conjunction with marginal improvements in the 6-min walk test and the floor transfer test. There were no significant changes in thigh muscle CSA adipose tissue in Optifast©. Overall, EMR was primarily effective in promoting positive changes in body composition and skeletal muscle in obese older adults.

The superior influence of EMR on whole body protein synthesis, protein breakdown, and net protein balance compared to a high protein meal replacement (ie., Bariatric Advantage) in obese older adults has been demonstrated using stable isotope methodology [14]. In these acute feeding studies using a randomized, cross-over design, the initial “proof of concept” was developed to hypothesize the physiological outcomes described herein. The profile of EAAs in EMR was formulated to optimize translation of protein synthesis and overcome anabolic resistance in the context of aging without a concomitant increase in calories [18]. Therefore, the daily provision of EMR over the course of 4 weeks provided the requisite nutrient-induced stimulus to promote thigh skeletal muscle accretion in obese older individuals. This beneficial alteration in musculature with EMR occurred without any change in physical activity or additional dietary manipulation. Unlike the potentially complicated use of growth hormone, testosterone, or other pharmaceutical approaches in medical practice [19], consumption of EMR q.d. can be self-administered in otherwise healthy, obese individuals. With the exception of modest fluctuations in total protein and blood urea nitrogen, markers of hepatic and kidney function were within normal limits at baseline and did not change over the course of the 4-week study with the consumption of either EMR or Optifast®.

MRI-, or computed tomography - derived measurement of thigh muscle CSA represents the gold standard for the evaluation of muscle mass, as these methods are near identical when compared to cadaveric data [20]. Therefore, the significant increase in thigh muscle CSA in EMR is particularly compelling. It is our assertion that EMR provides the requisite EAAs to overcome anabolic resistance. This may be facilitated by the optimization of intracellular translation in conjunction with the delivery of amino acid precursors needed to support optimal protein balance [18,21]. Combined with reductions in adipose tissue, increased thigh muscle CSA in those receiving EMR may have been translated to marginal improvements in the 6-min walk test and the floor transfer test; both of which have been closely associated with independent living in older adults [22,23]. Larger studies are warranted to explore the relationship between the provision of EAAs and improvements in physical function.

The reduction in whole body and visceral adipose tissue in the EMR group may have been modestly linked to the energy cost of accelerated protein synthesis [24]. For example, 20 kcals are used for every 1 mol of amino acids incorporated into muscle protein [25]. Based on a theoretical calculation using data from our previous isotope study, the stimulation of protein synthesis resulting from a single serving of EMR multiplied by 30 days would only account for an increased expenditure of 1596 ± 143 kcals. It is likely that the provision of EMR several times throughout the day and/or as part of a caloric restriction strategy would be even more beneficial in promoting reductions in adipose tissue.

In addition to our concerns related to sarcopenic obesity, we are aware that non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has reached epidemic proportions in older adults [26]. Closely associated with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome, NAFLD contributes to metabolic dysregulation and can lead to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, putting individuals at an increased risk for fibrosis, cirrhosis, and liver failure [27]. While the precise effects of increased amino acid intake upon NAFLD are still unclear, previous work has demonstrated that 11 g of EAAs provided twice daily reduced intrahepatic lipid and plasma lipids [28]. Pre-clinical studies suggest that energy requirements for amino acid metabolism may enhance the oxidation of intrahepatic lipid [29]. While some studies have suggested an association between elevated branched chain amino acid concentrations and insulin resistance [30–32], recent pre-clinical studies suggest that branched chain amino acids may foster reductions in liver fat through permissive alterations in the gut microbiome and portal acetic acid levels [33]. Without any detrimental alterations in metabolic parameters, there was a significant reduction in intrahepatic lipid with once/day supplementation of EAAs in the form of EMR (Fig. 3). Our results are consistent with literature in which branched chain amino acids were given to older individuals diagnosed with underlying etiology metabolic syndrome that may have included hepatic steatosis, without inducing or worsening insulin resistance [34,35].

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: There are some important limitations to our study. The overarching limitation is the small number of obese older participants enrolled for this proof of principle clinical trial. There was considerable homogeneity amongst the primary variables of body composition, thigh muscle CSA, and physical function even with the small sample size. That being said, we previously mentioned that two individuals were recruited for participation in the Optifast® group slightly outside the BMI range (ie., 43 and 44 kg/m2). This anomaly may have slightly affected the homogeneity of this variable in the Optifast® group. The normality assumption was violated for baseline levels of intrahepatic lipid in the Optifast® group. We identified an inadequate normality distribution using the Kolmogorov–Smirnov test and utilized the Wilcoxon Matched-Pairs Signed Ranks test for this particular outcome variable. It is also important to clarify that EMR provided 1/3 more total protein through the provision of individual essential amino acids and intact protein compared to Optifast®. Future studies will increase the sample size of our participants, monitor physical activity, and evaluate alcohol consumption that may be responsible for high levels of intrahepatic lipid [36]. Assessment of these parameters in future studies with higher numbers of participants using an intent to treat approach will also improve the overall interpretation of our approach.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The EMR approach is unique in that the anabolic influence of the EAAs can be maximized within the context of a single meal instead of multiple feedings throughout the day. The positive benefits of EMR among our older participants reported herein should be interpreted in the context of per protocol analytical approach which evaluates treatments under optimal conditions. Nevertheless, it is our assertion that structured interventions and/or alternatives to the utilization of EMR are time-consuming and tedious with limited pragmatic application in this cohort. These approaches seem to offer relatively modest benefits despite high financial costs and the need for direct clinical supervision [37]. Daily provision of EMR for just one month promoted a net gain of thigh muscle CSA, as well as significant reductions in total fat mass, visceral fat mass, and visceral fat volume. The provision of EMR also seemed to improve walking speed, which has been directly associated with reduced mortality and disability [38,39]. With respect to the limitations mentioned above, EMR may provide health benefits without the need for complicated and expensive medically supervised interventions.

We recognize Katie Axelarris, Kaylee Ladd, Claire Hughes, Michelle Johannsen and Jared Wood for their technical contributions. We would like to express our sincere appreciation to our participants from the Fairbanks area that volunteered their time and effort for this study.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Research reported in this publication was supported by Essential Blends, LLC. This research was also supported in part by the National Institute of General Medical Sciences of the National Institutes of Health under award P20GM130443 (Center for Transformative Research in Metabolism) and P20GM103395 (Alaska INBRE).
